CC48.7

ACTION 

Amended 

 

Ward:All 
Social Media Policy during an Election Year
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council adopt a policy on the Use of Social Media during the 2014 Election Campaign:

 

a.         If a Member of City Council uses any social media account for campaign purposes, such account must not be created or supported by City resources, or use the City of Toronto logo.

 

b.         To avoid confusion with any social media accounts used for Council Member work, Council Members who choose to create or use social media accounts for campaign communications include, for the duration of the campaign, a clear statement on each campaign account’s home page indicating that the account is being used for campaign purposes.

 

c.         Social media accounts used for campaign purposes must utilize personal cell phones, tablets and/or computers.

 

d.         For the purpose of the social media policy during an election year "Social Media" refers to freely accessible, third party hosted interactive web technologies used to produce, post and interact through text, images, video, and audio to inform, share, promote, collaborate or network.

 

2.         City Council amend the Constituency Services and Office Budget Policy to remove the bullet under section 4.7 b which reads "Link from the City’s website or the Councillor’s personal website to social media pages where campaign or election-related information is posted".

 

3.         City Council request the Integrity Commissioner to consult with Members of Council and report back to City Council after the election on any recommended amendments to the social media policy for future elections.

 

4.         City Council request the Integrity Commissioner to report back on a general Social Media policy for elected Members of Council, Members of Local Boards (restricted definition) and Members of Adjudicative Boards.

 

5.         City Council amend the Constituency Services and Office Budget Policy to permit print or electronic communications to constituents until the Nomination Day deadline to provide information before the election about urgent matters arising from the August 27 and 28, 2014 meeting of City Council.
City Council Decision Advice and Other Information

The Integrity Commissioner gave a presentation to Council on Social Media Policy during an Election Year.
Background Information (City Council)
(February 11, 2014) Report from the Integrity Commissioner on Social Media Policy during an Election Year (CC48.7)
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/cc/bgrd/backgroundfile-66935.pdf)
Attachment 1 - City of Toronto Guidelines for Social Media Use by Employees
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/cc/bgrd/backgroundfile-66936.pdf)
Attachment 2 - Sample Page from City of Seattle Website: Links to Member Pages and Social Media
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/cc/bgrd/backgroundfile-66937.pdf)
Attachment 3 - Description of Social Media Sites used by Members of Toronto City Council
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/cc/bgrd/backgroundfile-66938.pdf)
Attachment 4 - Statistics on Social Media Sites used by Members of Toronto City Council
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/cc/bgrd/backgroundfile-66939.pdf)
Motions (City Council)
1a - Motion to Amend Item moved by Councillor Sarah Doucette (Carried)

That City Council amend CC48.7 Recommendation 1 by adding the following new sections:

 

C.        Social media accounts used for campaign purposes must utilize personal cell phones, tablets and/or computers.

 

D.        For the purpose of the social media policy during an election year "Social Media" refers to freely accessible, third party hosted interactive web technologies used to produce, post and interact through text, images, video, and audio to inform, share, promote, collaborate or network.


Vote (Amend Item)

Feb-20-2014 4:26 PM
Result: Carried Majority Required - CC48.7 - Doucette - motion 1a
Yes: 35 Paul Ainslie, Ana Bail�o, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Josh Colle, Gary Crawford, Janet Davis, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Mike Del Grande, Frank Di Giorgio, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Doug Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Peter Milczyn, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, John Parker, James Pasternak, Gord Perks, Jaye Robinson, Karen Stintz, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam 
No: 3 Maria Augimeri, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Anthony Perruzza 
Absent: 7 Michelle Berardinetti, Vincent Crisanti, Rob Ford, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Giorgio Mammoliti, David Shiner, Michael Thompson 

1b - Motion to Amend Item moved by Councillor Sarah Doucette (Amended)

That:

 

1.         City Council amend CC48.7 Recommendation 1.A. by deleting the word "a" and replacing it with "any" so that Recommendation 1.A.now reads:

 

1.A.     if an elected Member of City Council uses any social media account for campaign purposes, such account may not be used for City purposes, must not be created or supported by City resources, and must not use the elected Member's title, or the City of Toronto logo. Existing accounts used by Council Members for their work as a councillor should not be re-designated as campaign sites or provide a link to a campaign site; and

 

2.         City Council amend CC48.7 Recommendation 1.B. by adding the word "any" so that Recommendation 1.B now reads:

 

1.B.     to avoid confusion with any social media accounts used for Council Member work, it is recommended that Council Members who choose to create or use social media accounts for campaign communications include, for the duration of the campaign, a clear statement on each campaign account’s home page indicating that the account is being used for campaign purposes.

 

Part 1 of motion 1b lost.


Vote (Amend Item)

Feb-20-2014 4:28 PM
Result: Lost Majority Required - CC48.7 - Doucette - motion 1b Part 1
Yes: 10 Paul Ainslie, Shelley Carroll, Janet Davis, Mike Del Grande, Sarah Doucette, Mark Grimes, Chin Lee, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Ron Moeser, Gord Perks 
No: 29 Maria Augimeri, Ana Bail�o, Raymond Cho, Josh Colle, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Frank Di Giorgio, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Doug Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Peter Leon, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Joe Mihevc, Peter Milczyn, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, John Parker, James Pasternak, Anthony Perruzza, Jaye Robinson, Karen Stintz, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam 
Absent: 6 Michelle Berardinetti, Rob Ford, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Giorgio Mammoliti, David Shiner, Michael Thompson 

Vote (Amend Item)

Feb-20-2014 4:29 PM
Result: Carried Majority Required - CC48.7 - Doucette - motion 1b Part 2
Yes: 29 Paul Ainslie, Shelley Carroll, Josh Colle, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Janet Davis, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Mike Del Grande, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Peter Milczyn, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, John Parker, Gord Perks, Jaye Robinson, Karen Stintz, Adam Vaughan 
No: 10 Maria Augimeri, Ana Bail�o, Raymond Cho, Frank Di Giorgio, Doug Ford, Mike Layton, Denzil Minnan-Wong, James Pasternak, Anthony Perruzza, Kristyn Wong-Tam 
Absent: 6 Michelle Berardinetti, Rob Ford, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Giorgio Mammoliti, David Shiner, Michael Thompson 

2 - Motion to Amend Item moved by Councillor Joe Mihevc (Carried)

That City Council delete CC48.7 Recommendation 1.A.

 

Recommendation to be deleted

 

A.        If an elected Member of City Council uses a social media account for campaign purposes, such account may not be used for City purposes, must not be created or supported by City resources, and must not use the elected Member's title, or the City of Toronto logo. Existing accounts used by Council Members for their work as a councillor should not be re-designated as campaign sites or provide a link to a campaign site.

 

and adopt instead new Recommendation 1.A. as follows:

 

A.        If a Member of City Council uses any social media account for campaign purposes, such account must not be created or supported by City resources, or use the City of Toronto logo.


Vote (Amend Item)

Feb-20-2014 4:30 PM
Result: Carried Majority Required - CC48.7 - Mihevc - motion 2
Yes: 35 Maria Augimeri, Ana Bail�o, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Josh Colle, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Mike Del Grande, Frank Di Giorgio, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Doug Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Joe Mihevc, Peter Milczyn, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, John Parker, James Pasternak, Anthony Perruzza, Jaye Robinson, Karen Stintz, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam 
No: 4 Paul Ainslie, Janet Davis, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Gord Perks

Member Motions - Meeting 48
MM48.1

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:All 
150th Anniversary of Canadian Confederation - by Councillor Paul Ainslie, seconded by Councillor Michael Thompson
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council direct the General Manager, Economic Development and Culture to engage with citizens and neighbouring municipalities to create a regional strategy for 2017, and host local sessions in libraries, arenas, and community centres to educate citizens about the Centennial and plan for the Sesquicentennial.

 

2.         City Council direct the General Manager, Economic Development and Culture to promote our community to the Provincial and Federal governments with a view to staging a major Sesquicentennial event in Toronto.

 

3.         City Council direct the General Manager, Economic Development and Culture to review our local Centennial history, and look to other past celebrations which may provide inspiration for 2017 planning.

 

4.         City Council direct the General Manager, Economic Development and Culture to create a Toronto: 2017 Planning Committee to begin forming partnerships, consulting with residents, residents associations, as well as private sector organizations in planning Toronto-based 2017 initiatives.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.1
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66905.pdf)
Motions (City Council)
Motion to Adopt Item (Carried)

Vote (Adopt Item)

Feb-20-2014 2:27 PM
Result: Carried Majority Required - MM48.1 - Adopt the item
Yes: 41 Paul Ainslie, Maria Augimeri, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Janet Davis, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Mike Del Grande, Frank Di Giorgio, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Doug Ford, Rob Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Peter Leon, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Peter Milczyn, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, John Parker, James Pasternak, Gord Perks, Anthony Perruzza, Jaye Robinson, David Shiner, Karen Stintz, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam

City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council increase the approved Parks, Forestry and Recreation 2014 Operating Budget by $115,000 gross, $0 net, fully funded by $50,000 in Section 37 funds received from the development at 5145 Dundas Street West (source XR3026-3700264), and by a $65,000 donation from the Islington Seniors' Centre, for the purpose of renovations to the kitchen areas of the Islington Seniors' Centre building at 4968 Dundas Street West.

 

2.         City Council authorize the Acting General Manager, Parks, Forestry and Recreation to enter into an agreement with Islington Seniors' Centre to spend the donated funds for the renovations to 4968 Dundas Street West on terms and conditions satisfactory to the Acting General Manager, Parks, Forestry and Recreation, and in a form and content satisfactory to the City Solicitor.

MM48.8

ACTION 

Amended 

 

Ward:All 
Request to maintain Canada Post Services - by Councillor Michelle Berardinetti, seconded by Councillor Peter Leon
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council request the City Manager to convey to the Federal Minister responsible for Canada Post, the Honourable Lisa Raitt, that the Federal Government should direct Canada Post to maintain the current system of residential door-to-door delivery in Canada.

 

2.         City Council request the Federal Government and Canada Post to publicly release the report Banking: A Proven Diversification Strategy.

 

3.         City Council direct the City Manager to forward this resolution to the Federation of Canadian Municipalities.

 

4.         City Council direct the City Manager, in consultation with the appropriate City staff, to report back to Council, through the Executive Committee, on:

 

a.         the potential cost of the reduced Canada Post service to the City including the requirement of municipal land and rights-of-way, infrastructure such as paving and lighting and policing related to vandalism, graffiti and mail theft;

 

b.         which communities and neighbourhoods in the City will be affected;

 

c.         the demographics of such areas;

 

d.         what change to service will be implemented in these areas, where will postal boxes be located; and

 

e.         the impact of these changes on the public realm.

 

5.         City Council request the City Manager to report to the Executive Committee on the potential implications of the loss of Canada Post delivery to the citizens of Toronto, especially seniors and persons with disabilities, as well as crime and safety issues such as identity theft.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.8
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66914.pdf)
Motions (City Council)
Motion to Waive Referral (Carried)

Speaker Nunziata advised Council that the provisions of Chapter 27, Council Procedures, require that Motion MM48.8 be referred to the Executive Committee.  A two-thirds vote of the Council Members present is required to waive referral.


Vote (Waive Referral)

Feb-20-2014 2:40 PM
Result: Carried Two-Thirds Required - MM48.8 - Waive referral
Yes: 37 Paul Ainslie, Maria Augimeri, Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Raymond Cho, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Janet Davis, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Mike Del Grande, Frank Di Giorgio, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Doug Ford, Rob Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Peter Milczyn, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, James Pasternak, Gord Perks, Anthony Perruzza, Jaye Robinson, David Shiner, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan 
No: 6 Shelley Carroll, Norman Kelly, Denzil Minnan-Wong, John Parker, Karen Stintz, Kristyn Wong-Tam 
Absent: 2 Josh Colle, Giorgio Mammoliti 

1 - Motion to Amend Item (Additional) moved by Councillor Kristyn Wong-Tam (Carried)

That:

 

1.         City Council request the Federal Government and Canada Post to publicly release the report Banking: A Proven Diversification Strategy.

 

2.         City Council direct the City Manager to forward this resolution to the Federation of Canadian Municipalities.

 

3.         City Council direct the City Manager, in consultation with the appropriate City staff, to report back to Council through the Executive Committee on:

 

a.         the potential cost of the reduced Canada Post service to the City including the requirement of municipal land and rights-of-way, infrastructure such as paving and lighting and policing related to vandalism, graffiti and mail theft;

 

b.         which communities and neighbourhoods in the City will be affected;

 

c.         the demographics of such areas;

 

d.         what change to service will be implemented in these areas, where will postal boxes be located; and

 

e.         the impact of these changes on the public realm.


Vote (Amend Item (Additional))

Feb-20-2014 7:33 PM
Result: Carried Majority Required - MM48.8 - Wong-Tam - motion 1
Yes: 39 Paul Ainslie, Maria Augimeri, Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Josh Colle, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Janet Davis, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Mike Del Grande, Frank Di Giorgio, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Doug Ford, Rob Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Josh Matlow, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, Gord Perks, Anthony Perruzza, Jaye Robinson, David Shiner, Karen Stintz, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam 
No: 2 Denzil Minnan-Wong, John Parker 
Absent: 4 Giorgio Mammoliti, Pam McConnell, Peter Milczyn, James Pasternak 

2 - Motion to Amend Item (Additional) moved by Councillor Glenn De Baeremaeker (Carried)

That City Council request the City Manager to report to the Executive Committee on the potential implications of the loss of Canada Post delivery to the citizens of Toronto, especially seniors and persons with disabilities, as well as crime and safety issues such as identity theft.

MM48.10

ACTION 

Amended 

 

Ward:All 
Extension of Alcohol Sales and Service Hours During the 2014 Winter Olympics - by Councillor Mike Layton, seconded by Councillor Michael Thompson
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council authorize the extension of alcohol sales and service hours in the City of Toronto, in areas other than the Wards identified in Part 2 below to begin at 7:00 a.m. on February 22 and February 23, 2014 to allow local cafes and restaurants to take advantage of the economic opportunities of this major international event.

 

2.         City Council, at the request of the associated local Ward Councillors, not include the following Wards as part of the extension of alcohol sales and service hours in the City of Toronto:

 

- Ward 9 - York Centre

- Ward 11 – York South – Weston

- Ward 24 - Willowdale

 

3.         City Council not extend the extension of alcohol sales and service hours to any establishments licensed as "nightclubs", license category B97 (Entertainment District).

 

4.         City Council authorize the City Solicitor to introduce a by-law substantially as set out in this Motion.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.10
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66916.pdf)
Appendix 1 - Draft By-law
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66921.pdf)
(February 17, 2014) Supplementary Report from the General Manager, Economic Development and Culture on Extension of Alcohol Sales and Service Hours During the 2014 Winter Olympics (MM48.10a)
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67034.pdf)
Motions (City Council)
Motion to Waive Referral (Carried)

Speaker Nunziata advised Council that the provisions of Chapter 27, Council Procedures, require that Motion MM48.10 be referred to the Economic Development Committee.  A two-thirds vote of the Council Members present is required to waive referral.


Vote (Waive Referral)

Feb-20-2014 2:42 PM
Result: Carried Two-Thirds Required - MM48.10. - Waive referral
Yes: 41 Paul Ainslie, Maria Augimeri, Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Janet Davis, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Frank Di Giorgio, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Doug Ford, Rob Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Peter Milczyn, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, John Parker, James Pasternak, Gord Perks, Anthony Perruzza, Jaye Robinson, David Shiner, Karen Stintz, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam 
No: 2 Mike Del Grande, Ron Moeser 
Absent: 2 Josh Colle, Giorgio Mammoliti 

1 - Motion to Adopt Item as Amended moved by Councillor Mike Layton (Carried)

That City Council delete the recommendations in Member Motion MM48.10 and replace them with the following new recommendations:

 

1.         City Council authorize the extension of alcohol sales and service hours in the City of Toronto, in areas other than the Wards identified in Recommendation 2, to begin at 7:00 a.m. on February 22 and February 23, 2014 to allow local cafes and restaurants to take advantage of the economic opportunities of this major international event.

 

2.         City Council, at the request of the associated local Ward Councillors, not include the following Wards as part of the extension of alcohol sales and service hours in the City of Toronto:

 

- Ward 9 - York Centre

- Ward 11 – York South – Weston

- Ward 24 - Willowdale

 

3.         City Council not extend the extension of alcohol sales and service hours to any establishments licensed as "nightclubs", license category B97 (Entertainment District).

 

4.         City Council authorize the City Solicitor to introduce a by-law substantially as set out in this Motion.


Vote (Adopt Item as Amended)

Feb-20-2014 7:24 PM
Result: Carried Majority Required - MM48.10 - Layton - motion 1 - Adopt the item as amended
Yes: 37 Maria Augimeri, Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Josh Colle, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Janet Davis, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Frank Di Giorgio, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Doug Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, Gord Perks, Anthony Perruzza, Jaye Robinson, Karen Stintz, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam

MM48.11

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:19 
Liquor Licence Application for Increased Capacity - 2270121 Ontario Inc. operating as Church Aperitivo Bar, 1090 Queen Street West, - Licence Number 814239 - by Councillor Mike Layton, seconded by Councillor Gord Perks
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council direct the City Clerk to advise the Registrar of the Alcohol and Gaming Commission of Ontario (“AGCO”) that the liquor licence expansion application for Church Aperitivo, 1090 Queen Street West (the “Premises”), is not in the public interest having regard to the needs and wishes of the residents, and that the Registrar should issue a Proposal to Review the liquor licence expansion application.

 

2.         City Council request the AGCO and the Licence Appeal Tribunal (“LAT”) to provide the City of Toronto with an opportunity to participate in any additional proceedings with respect to the Premises.

 

3.         City Council authorize the City Solicitor to attend all proceedings before the AGCO and the LAT in this matter and direct the City Solicitor to take all necessary actions so as to give effect to this Motion, including adding and deleting conditions to the current liquor licence issued for the Premises in consultation with the Ward Councillor, which address issues including, but not limited to, noise, safety, security personnel, security cameras, crowd control, signage, lighting and litter.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.11
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66918.pdf)
Motions (City Council)
Motion to Waive Referral (Carried)

Speaker Nunziata advised Council that the provisions of Chapter 27, Council Procedures, require that Motion MM48.11 be referred to the Toronto and East York Community Council.  A two-thirds vote of the Council Members present is required to waive referral.


Vote (Waive Referral)

MM48.12

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:All 
Providing Authority for Staff to Take the Next Steps in the process to designate Public Lands along the Humber and Don River Valleys and the Etobicoke Creek as part of the Greenbelt - by Councillor Glenn De Baeremaeker, seconded by Councillor Maria Augimeri
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council direct the Chief Planner and Executive Director, City Planning, in conjunction with the appropriate City staff, to begin the process of making an application to the Province for Urban River Valley designation for public lands in the Humber and Don River Valleys and Etobicoke Creek. Specifically, City staff shall:

 

            a.         initiate coordination with other public landowners to identify lands suitable for Urban River Valley designation;

 

             b.        develop a cost estimation for the Urban River Valley designation;

 

            c.         work with the Province of Ontario to agree on the scope and extent of public consultation required before proceeding;

 

             d.        work with the Province of Ontario on ways in which the Greenbelt Plan can be improved to better assist municipalities with Urban River Valley-designated lands in necessary restoration and stewardship actions; and

 

            e.         report back to the Planning and Growth Management Committee by May 2014 with a plan and cost estimates to expand the Provincial Greenbelt by designating selected public lands as Urban River Valley, as outlined in Provincial legislation.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.12
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66917.pdf)
Motions (City Council)
Motion to Waive Referral (Carried)

Speaker Nunziata advised Council that the provisions of Chapter 27, Council Procedures, require that Motion MM48.12 be referred to the Planning and Growth Management Committee.  A two-thirds vote of the Council Members present is required to waive referral.


Vote (Waive Referral)

No: 11 Ana Bail�o, Shelley Carroll, Janet Davis, Mike Del Grande, Doug Ford, Norman Kelly, Frances Nunziata (Chair), John Parker, James Pasternak, David Shiner, Michael Thompson

MM48.14

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:All 
Declaration of Hispanic Heritage Month for the month of October - by Councillor Cesar Palacio, seconded by Deputy Mayor Norm Kelly
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         Toronto City Council formally declare October as "Hispanic Heritage Month" for the entire City in 2014, and for future years.

 

2.         Toronto City Council formally request the Province of Ontario to declare October as "Hispanic Heritage Month" for the entire Province in 2014, and for future years.

 

3.         Toronto City Council formally request the Government of Canada to declare October as “Hispanic Heritage Month” for the entire Country in 2014, and for future years.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.14
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66953.pdf)
Letters in support of Hispanic Heritage Month, from Claudio Ruiz-Pilarte, The Centre for Spanish-Speaking People; Nuria L. Rajo, Canadian Hispanic Congress; Fernando Valladares, Hispanic Fiesta; Fernando Valladares, Las Flores Non-Profit Housing Corporation; Margarita Feliciano, Cultural Celebration of the Spanish Language; Jorge Patricio Viera, Association of Ecuadorians in Ontario; and Eduardo Harari, Hispanic Political Affairs Committee of Canada
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66956.pdf)
Communications (City Council)

(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/comm/communicationfile-45541.pdf)
Motions (City Council)

Speaker Nunziata advised Council that the provisions of Chapter 27, Council Procedures, require that Motion MM48.14 be referred to the Economic Development Committee.  A two-thirds vote of the Council Members present is required to waive referral.

MM48.15

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:10 
Authorization to Release Section 37 Funds from 929-939 Sheppard Avenue West for a Commemorative Heritage Plaque in Earl Bales Park - by Councillor James Pasternak, seconded by Councillor Peter Leon
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council increase the approved 2014 Operating Budget for Heritage Toronto by $4,500.00 gross, $0 net, fully funded by Section 37 community benefits secured in the development at 929-939 Sheppard Avenue West, (source account XR3026-3700124) for a heritage plaque commemorating the history of the John Bales House in Earl Bales Park.

Feb-20-2014 2:55 PM
Result: Carried Majority Required - MM48.15 - Adopt the item
Yes: 40 Paul Ainslie, Maria Augimeri, Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Mike Del Grande, Frank Di Giorgio, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Rob Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Peter Milczyn, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, John Parker, James Pasternak, Gord Perks, Anthony Perruzza, Jaye Robinson, David Shiner, Karen Stintz, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam

MM48.16

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:All 
Retrofitting Seniors Homes with Automatic Sprinkler Systems - by Councillor Joe Mihevc, seconded by Councillor Glenn De Baeremaeker
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council request the City Manager to write to the Premier of Ontario and the Minister of Municipal Affairs and Housing, and request that the Province expedite the timelines for retrofits to require sprinklers; and that the Province consider a low interest loan program to encourage faster retrofits of multi-residential buildings to include automatic sprinklers.

MM48.17

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:All 
Commemorating the 100th Anniversary of the Battle of Vimy Ridge - by Councillor James Pasternak, seconded by Councillor Josh Matlow
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council request the City Manager, in conjunction with the City Clerk, to report back to City Council on a strategy such that:

 

a.         Toronto can host events during the week of April 9, 2017 across the City to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Battle of Vimy Ridge. Events could include but not be limited to ceremonies in Civic Centres, community centres and at war memorials;

 

b.         a strategic working group be assembled that would include veterans groups, families of Canadian World War I soldiers and community partners to play a leadership role in this endeavour; and

 

c.         any plan moving forward includes intergovernmental coordination with Federal and Provincial counterparts.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.17
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66955.pdf)
Motions (City Council)
Motion to Waive Referral (Carried)

Speaker Nunziata advised Council that the provisions of Chapter 27, Council Procedures, require that Motion MM48.17 be referred to the Economic Development Committee.  A two-thirds vote of the Council Members present is required to waive referral.

MM48.19

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:All 
Protecting Toronto's Tenants: Above the Guideline Rent Increase Reform - by Councillor Josh Matlow, seconded by Councillor John Parker
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council request the Province of Ontario to amend section 126 of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006, to:

 

a.         eliminate a Landlord's ability to levy an Above the Guideline Rent Increase for costs prescribed in subsection (1)1 relating to the municipal taxes and utilities;

 

b.         eliminate eligibility of capital expenditures for the purpose of an Above the Guideline Rent Increase under the categories prescribed in subsection (7) a, b and c that constitute general repair and maintenance of the property;

 

c.         add new subsection requiring Landlords to save 10% of rental income for a maintenance account to be accessed for capital expenditures related to the categories prescribed subsection (7) a, b and c; and

 

d.         provide that no rent increases be permitted related to the enactment of Parts 1.a. and b above.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.19
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66923.pdf)
Motions (City Council)
Motion to Waive Referral (Carried)

Speaker Nunziata advised Council that the provisions of Chapter 27, Council Procedures, require that Motion MM48.19 be referred to the Executive Committee.  A two-thirds vote of the Council Members present is required to waive referral.


Vote (Waive Referral)

Feb-20-2014 3:16 PM
Result: Carried Two-Thirds Required - MM48.19 - Waive referral
Yes: 31 Paul Ainslie, Maria Augimeri, Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Raymond Cho, Josh Colle, Gary Crawford, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Frank Di Giorgio, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Doug Ford, Rob Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Peter Milczyn, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, Gord Perks, Anthony Perruzza, Jaye Robinson, Michael Thompson, Kristyn Wong-Tam

MM48.21

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:27 
625, 629 and 637 Yonge Street and 1, 3, 5, 7 and 9 Isabella Street - Zoning Amendment Application - Request for Directions Report - by Councillor Kristyn Wong-Tam, seconded by Councillor Pam McConnell
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council request the Director, Community Planning, Toronto and East York District to bring a Directions Report on the Zoning By-law Amendment application for 625, 629 and 637 Yonge Street and 1, 3, 5, 7 and 9 Isabella Street (File: 12 260124 STE 27 OZ) to the Toronto and East York Community Council in 2014.

 

2.         City Council request the Director, Community Planning, Toronto and East York District initiate an amendment to the Official Plan to create a "site and area specific policy" for the block bounded by Yonge Street to the west, Isabella Street to the north, Gloucester Street to the south, and Gloucester Lane to the east, generally stating that the block contain a maximum of two tall buildings, with a minimum separation of 25 metres between the face of the tall building towers; and, that the amendment be scheduled for consideration at the same Toronto and East York Community Council meeting as the revised Zoning By-law Amendment application for 625, 629 and 637 Yonge Street and 1, 3, 5, 7 and 9 Isabella Street.

 

3.         City Council direct the appropriate staff to schedule a community consultation meeting for the proposed Official Plan amendment with the Ward Councillor.

 

4.         City Council direct that Notice for the community consultation meeting be given to landowners and residents within 120 metres of the site.

 

5.         City Council direct that Notice for the public meeting under the Planning Act be given according to the regulations under the Planning Act.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.21
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67064.pdf)

MM48.23

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:5 
Request to Accept a Donation from the Maple Leafs Sports and Entertainment Foundation for Upgrades to Central Arena - by Councillor Peter Milczyn, seconded by Councillor Sarah Doucette
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

 1.        City Council authorize the General Manager, Parks, Forestry and Recreation to accept the donation from the Maple Leaf Sports and Entertainment Foundation in the amount of $50,000 for upgrades to Central Arena in accordance with the Policy on Donations to the City of Toronto for Community Benefits.

 

2.         City Council amend the 2014 Operating Budget for Parks, Forestry and Recreation by $50,000 gross and $0 net.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM 48.23
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67061.pdf)

Ward:30 
Extending the Ice Skating Season on Monarch Park Rink - by Councillor Paula Fletcher, seconded by Councillor John Filion
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council request the General Manager, Parks, Forestry and Recreation to keep the artificial ice rink at Monarch Park in operation up to and including the March Break, weather and budget permitting.

Extending the Ice Skating Season on Monarch Park Rink

MM48.25

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:32 
1880-1882 Queen Street East - Request for Direction on OMB Hearing- by Councillor Mary-Margaret McMahon, seconded by Councillor Adam Vaughan
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council adopt the recommendations contained in Confidential Attachment 1 to the report (February 14, 2014) from the City Solicitor.

 

2.         City Council direct that the recommendations contained in Confidential Attachment 1 to the report (February 14, 2014) from the City Solicitor and the information contained in Appendix "A" be made public at such time as City Council adopts the recommendations and that all other information contained in Confidential Attachment 1 remain confidential.

 

The recommendations contained in Confidential Attachment 1 to the report (February 14, 2014) from the City Solicitor were adopted by City Council and are now public:

 

1.         City Council accept the settlement offer negotiated by all of the parties to the hearing as set out in Appendix "A" to the report (February 14, 2014) from the City Solicitor and authorize the City Solicitor to execute Minutes of Settlement which give effect to this settlement.

 

2.         City Council authorize the City Solicitor and appropriate City Staff to attend at the OMB hearing into this matter in support of the settlement discussed in Part 1 above.

 

The confidential information contained in Appendix A to the report (February 14, 2014) from the City Solicitor is now public and can be accessed under Background Information (City Council).

 

The balance of Confidential Attachment 1 to the report (February 14, 2014) from the City Solicitor remains confidential in its entirety in accordance with the provisions of the City of Toronto Act, 2006, as it contains information that is subject to solicitor-client privilege and it pertains to litigation or potential litigation, including matters before administrative tribunals, affecting the municipality or local board.
Confidential Attachment - The receiving of advice that is subject to solicitor-client privilege and litigation or potential litigation, including matters before administrative tribunals, affecting the municipality or local board
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.25
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67037.pdf)
(February 14, 2014) Report from the City Solicitor on 1880-1882 Queen Street East - Request for directions regarding the February 24, 2014 OMB Hearing
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67038.pdf)
Confidential Attachment 1
Appendix A - made public on February 26, 2014
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67256.pdf)

This Motion is brought forward on an urgent basis as a two week hearing is scheduled to commence on February 24, 2014.  Additional information has been received and staff require Council's instructions.

MM48.27

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:24 
Potential Relocation from 251 Esther Shiner Boulevard - Oriole Yard - by Councillor David Shiner, seconded by Councillor Peter Leon
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council amend its November 13, 14, 15 and 18, 2013 decision on Item EX35.18 by rescinding the request that staff report to the Executive Committee and instead requesting the Director, Real Estate Services, in consultation with the General Manager, Transportation Services and the Acting General Manager, Parks, Forestry and Recreation to report to the Government Management Committee in May 2014 with respect to recommendations and operational impacts of the relocation from Oriole Yard, as per the Yard Property Utilization Initiative adopted by City Council on November 27, 2012.
City Council Decision Advice and Other Information

City Council re-opened Item EX35.18 adopted by City Council on November 13, 14, 15 and 18, 2013, only as it pertains to the request for staff to report to the Executive Committee.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.27
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67041.pdf)
Motions (City Council)
Motion to Introduce Motion without Notice moved by Councillor David Shiner (Carried)

That Councillor Shiner be permitted to add to the agenda of today's meeting an urgent Motion without notice concerning:
 

Potential Relocation from 251 Esther Shiner Boulevard - Oriole Yard

 
Reason for Urgency:
 
This motion is urgent as this matter should be considered at the Government Management Committee meeting held on May 12, 2014.  In order to meet the agenda timetable requirements for the May meeting of Government Management Committee, it is important that this is considered now.


Vote (Introduce Motion without Notice)

Feb-19-2014 2:33 PM
Result: Carried Two-Thirds full Council Required - Shiner - Add Urgent Motion
Yes: 41 Paul Ainslie, Maria Augimeri, Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Josh Colle, Gary Crawford, Janet Davis, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Frank Di Giorgio, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Doug Ford, Rob Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Giorgio Mammoliti, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Peter Milczyn, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Ron Moeser, Cesar Palacio, John Parker (Chair), James Pasternak, Gord Perks, Anthony Perruzza, David Shiner, Karen Stintz, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam

Feb-20-2014 7:16 PM

Yes: 41 Paul Ainslie, Maria Augimeri, Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Josh Colle, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Janet Davis, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Mike Del Grande, Frank Di Giorgio, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Doug Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, John Parker, Gord Perks, Anthony Perruzza, Jaye Robinson, David Shiner, Karen Stintz, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam 
No: 1 Rob Ford 
Absent: 3 Giorgio Mammoliti, Peter Milczyn, James Pasternak 

Point of Order by Councillor Gord Perks

Councillor Perks, rising on a Point of Order, stated that Councillor Shiner's Motion without Notice contained insufficient information to justify the urgency of the matter.  Councillor Perks further requested that such information be included in future Motions without Notice.


Ruling by Deputy Speaker John Parker
Deputy Speaker Parker accepted the Point of Order and took Councillor Perks's concerns under advisement.

ACTION

City Council Decision

(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67043.pdf)

Staff Representation at an Ontario Municipal Board Hearing for 142 Cameron Avenue
 
Reason for Urgency:

MM48.29

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:20 
231-237 College and 177-189 Huron Street - Technical Amendment to By-law No. 1675-2013 - by Councillor Adam Vaughan, seconded by Councillor Joe Mihevc
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council amend By-law 1675-2013 by replacing the text for subsection 1(e) in the by-law with the revised text attached to this Motion.

 

2.         City Council direct the City Solicitor to bring forward to Council’s meeting of March 20, 2014 for enactment by Council, a by-law to make the changes to By-law 1675-2013 noted in Part 1 above.

 

3.         City Council determine that, pursuant to Section 34(17) of the Planning Act, no further notice is to be given in respect of the changes to By-law 1675-2013.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.29
Motions (City Council)
Motion to Introduce Motion without Notice moved by Councillor Adam Vaughan (Carried)

That Councillor Vaughan be permitted to add to the agenda of today's meeting an urgent Motion without notice concerning:
 
231-237 College and 177-189 Huron Street – Technical Amendment to By-law No. 1675-2013
 
Reason for Urgency:
 
This is an urgent matter because the City-wide City of Toronto Zoning By-law was enacted almost a year ago and further delay may cause hardship to the property owner.

MM48.30

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:All 
Amending the Composition of the Toronto Music Industry Advisory Council - by Councillor Michael Thompson, seconded by Councillor Shelley Carroll
City Council Decision

City Council, on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council increase the composition of the Toronto Music Industry Advisory Council by one additional Councillor at-large, so that the composition will now be up to 35 Members, including two (2) Councillors at-large.
City Council Decision Advice and Other Information

City Council re-opened Item ED27.2 (City Council – December 16, 17 and 18, 2013) for further consideration as it pertains to the number of Council Member at-large positions on the Toronto Music Industry Advisory Council.  City Council subsequently appointed Members of Council to the Toronto Music Industry Advisory Council under Items ED28.11 and ST13.2.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.30
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67042.pdf)
Motions (City Council)
Motion to Introduce Motion without Notice moved by Councillor Michael Thompson (Carried)

That Councillor Thompson be permitted to add to the agenda of today's meeting an urgent Motion without notice concerning:
 

Amending the Composition of the Toronto Music Industry Advisory Council

 
Reason for Urgency:
 
This motion is urgent as the appointment of Council Members to the Toronto Music Industry Advisory Council is before the February 19 and 20, 2014 Council meeting.


Vote (Introduce Motion without Notice)

Feb-20-2014 12:00 PM
Result: Carried Two-Thirds full Council Required - Thompson - Add Urgent Motion

MM48.31

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:All 
Chief Executive Officer Search - Hummingbird (Sony) Centre for the Performing Arts - by Councillor Paula Fletcher, seconded by Councillor Pam McConnell
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council request the Hummingbird (Sony) Centre for the Performing Arts Board of Directors, during its search process for and appointment of a new Chief Executive Officer, to:

 

a.         ensure that candidates for the Chief Executive Officer position are informed that the Theatres Working Group will explore closer working relationships between the three civic theatres, including the potential for a shared vision, and make recommendations to the City on the mandates of the theatres, as set out in the motion adopted by each of the three theatre boards in October 2013 [EX36.6, December 2013];

 

b.         ensure that candidates for the Chief Executive Officer position are informed that the City, with the Theatres Working Group and external advisors, is undertaking a study to recommend options for future governance and potential operating models for the theatres [EX36.6 December 2013]; and

 

c.         ensure that the appointment of a new Chief Executive Officer is made on the basis of a short-term or flexible employment contract that meets the objectives of the City and the Hummingbird (Sony) Centre for the Performing Arts Board of Directors.

 

2.         City Council request the Chair of the Board of Directors of the Hummingbird (Sony) Centre for the Performing Arts to provide, through the City Manager, confidential information to City Council setting out the Chief Executive Officer selection process undertaken and conclusions reached by the Board prior to the Board finalizing its selection of a candidate for the position of Chief Executive Officer, and to attend the meeting of City Council at which the report will be considered.

 

3.         City Council direct the City Solicitor to provide appropriate support to the Chair of the Board and to the Board of Directors of the Hummingbird (Sony) Centre for the Performing Arts in the preparation of offers of employment and employment contracts arising from the Board’s Chief Executive Officer selection process.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.31
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67091.pdf)
Communications (City Council)
(February 20, 2014) E-mail from Ronald Forbes, Chair, Board of Directors, Sony Centre for the Performing Arts (MM.New.MM48.31.1)
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/comm/communicationfile-45542.pdf)
Motions (City Council)
Motion to Introduce Motion without Notice moved by Councillor Gary Crawford (Carried)

That Councillor Fletcher be permitted to add to the agenda of today's meeting an urgent Motion without notice concerning:

 

Chief Executive Officer Search – Hummingbird (Sony) Centre for the Performing Arts

 

Reason for Urgency:

 

This Motion is urgent as the search for a new Chief Executive Officer is already underway.


Vote (Introduce Motion without Notice)

Feb-20-2014 12:02 PM

MM48.32

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:All 
Lowering the Canadian flag to half mast in Nathan Phillips Square - Recognition of loss of life in the City of Kyiv, Ukraine - by Deputy Mayor Norman Kelly, seconded by Councillor Gloria Lindsay Luby
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council direct that the Canadian flag be lowered to half mast in Nathan Phillips Square in memory of the brave demonstrators who have recently lost their lives in our Sister City Kyiv, Ukraine, during their struggle to uphold the very democratic principles we value and promote in Toronto.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.32
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67097.pdf)
Motions (City Council)
Motion to Amend the Order Paper moved by Councillor Janet Davis (Carried)

February 20, 2014 at 11:40 a.m. - That City Council vary the proceedings to consider adding a Motion with Notice by Deputy Mayor Kelly to the agenda.


Vote (Amend the Order Paper)

Feb-20-2014 11:42 AM
Result: Carried Two-Thirds Required - RM48.6 - Immediately consider adding a Motion without Notice
Yes: 36 Paul Ainslie, Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Josh Colle, Vincent Crisanti, Janet Davis, Mike Del Grande, Frank Di Giorgio, Sarah Doucette, Doug Ford, Rob Ford, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Giorgio Mammoliti, Josh Matlow, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Peter Milczyn, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, John Parker, James Pasternak, Gord Perks, Anthony Perruzza, David Shiner, Karen Stintz, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam 
No: 0  
Absent: 9 Maria Augimeri, Gary Crawford, Glenn De Baeremaeker, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Pam McConnell, Jaye Robinson 

Motion to Introduce Motion without Notice moved by Deputy Mayor Norman Kelly (Carried)

That Deputy Mayor Kelly be permitted to add to the agenda of today's meeting a Motion without notice concerning:

 

Lowering the Canadian flag to half mast in Nathan Phillips Square – Recognition of loss of life in the City of Kyiv, Ukraine


Vote (Introduce Motion without Notice)

Feb-20-2014 11:49 AM
Result: Carried Two-Thirds full Council Required - Add motion without notice
Yes: 37 Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Josh Colle, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Janet Davis, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Mike Del Grande, Frank Di Giorgio, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Doug Ford, Rob Ford, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Giorgio Mammoliti, Josh Matlow, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Peter Milczyn, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata, Cesar Palacio, John Parker (Chair), James Pasternak, Gord Perks, Anthony Perruzza, David Shiner, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam

Vote (Adopt Item)

Feb-20-2014 11:54 AM
Result: Carried Majority Required - MM48.32 - Adopt the item
Yes: 38 Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Josh Colle, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Janet Davis, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Mike Del Grande, Frank Di Giorgio, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Doug Ford, Rob Ford, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Josh Matlow, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Peter Milczyn, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata, Cesar Palacio, John Parker (Chair), James Pasternak, Gord Perks, Anthony Perruzza, David Shiner, Karen Stintz, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam 
No: 0  
Absent: 7 Paul Ainslie, Maria Augimeri, Paula Fletcher, Mary Fragedakis, Giorgio Mammoliti, Pam McConnell, Jaye Robinson 

Point of Privilege by Mayor Rob Ford

Mayor Ford, rising on a Point of Privilege, stated that the Canadian flag should be lowered to half mast out of respect for the citizens of Kyiv, Ukraine who have lost their lives.  Mayor Ford stated that he hoped Members would support him in this request.


Point of Order by Deputy Mayor Norman Kelly

Deputy Mayor Kelly, rising on a Point of Order, stated that he had a prepared Motion without Notice to request that the Canadian flag be flown at half mast out of respect for the citizens of Kyiv, Ukraine who have recently lost their lives.


Point of Order by Councillor Giorgio Mammoliti

Councillor Mammoliti, rising on a Point of Order, requested that Council first consider Mayor Ford's request to fly the Canadian flag at half mast.


Ruling by Deputy Speaker John Parker
Deputy Speaker Parker accepted Mayor Ford's Point of Privilege and Councillor Mammoliti's and Deputy Mayor Kelly's Points of Order. Deputy Speaker Parker advised that it was the will of Council to consider Deputy Mayor Kelly's Motion without Notice on this matter.

MM48.33

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:All 
Revisions to Rush Hour Stopping/Standing/Parking Offences - Clarifying Regulations and Enforcement - by Councillor Denzil Minnan-Wong, seconded by Councillor Josh Matlow
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council approve the removal of rush hour offences as they apply to "No Parking" during rush hour periods, as follows: 

 

a.         by amending Subsection 950-101B.1 in Municipal Code Chapter 950, Traffic and Parking, to delete the phrase: "950-405A.1," with respect to the definition of the term "RUSH HOUR PERIOD" as it applies to "No parking during rush hour times.";

 

b.         by amending Municipal Code Chapter 950, Traffic and Parking, to delete Subsection 950-405A.1, "No parking during rush hour times."; and

 

c.         by amending Municipal Code Chapter 950, Traffic and Parking, to delete from the table to Subsection 950-1201A, the table of fixed fines for stopping, standing or parking offences, reference to Subsection 950-405A.1 ("No parking during rush hour times.") and the associated $150.00 fine.

 

2.         City Council, to clarify "No Stopping" offences during rush hour periods, amend Subsection 950-405D.1, "No stopping during rush hour times", by inserting the phrase: "where the hours as set out under Column four (Prohibited Times and/or Days) in Schedule XIV begin, end and are contained entirely within the time period of 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 a.m. and/or the time period of  3:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. of the rush hour period" after the phrase "under Column four (Prohibited Times and/or Days) in Schedule XIV".

 

3.         City Council, to clarify "No Standing" offences during rush hour periods, amend Subsection 950-405G.1, "No standing during rush hour times", by inserting the phrase: "where the hours as set out under Column four (Prohibited Times and/or Days) in Schedule XVI begin, end and are contained entirely within the time period of 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 a.m. and./or the time period of 3:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. of the rush hour period" after the phrase "under Column four (Prohibited Times and/or Days) in Schedule XVI".

 

4.         City Council direct the City Solicitor to submit the necessary bills to make such by-law amendments, including those necessary to make amendments to City of Toronto Municipal Code Chapter 903, Parking for Persons with Disabilities, if required, as may be required to give effect to Council's decision.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.33
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67080.pdf)
Motions (City Council)
Motion to Introduce Motion without Notice moved by Councillor Denzil Minnan-Wong (Carried)

That Councillor Minnan-Wong be permitted to add to the agenda of today's meeting an urgent Motion without notice concerning:

 

Revisions to Rush Hour Stopping/Standing/Parking Offences – Clarifying Regulations and Enforcement

 

Reason for Urgency:

 

This Motion is urgent as the current by-law is resulting in parking tickets being issued at rush hour rates ($150.00) in locations that would not be considered rush hour routes.  Immediate clarification of by-law language is required to ensure greater consistency and facilitate enforcement.


Vote (Introduce Motion without Notice)

Feb-20-2014 12:03 PM
Result: Carried Two-Thirds full Council Required - Minnan-Wong - Add Urgent Motion
Yes: 35 Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Josh Colle, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Janet Davis, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Mike Del Grande, Frank Di Giorgio, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Doug Ford, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Josh Matlow, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Peter Milczyn, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Ron Moeser, Cesar Palacio, John Parker (Chair), James Pasternak, Gord Perks, Anthony Perruzza, David Shiner, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam 
No: 0  
Absent: 10 Paul Ainslie, Maria Augimeri, Paula Fletcher, Rob Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Giorgio Mammoliti, Pam McConnell, Frances Nunziata, Jaye Robinson, Karen Stintz 

Motion to Adopt Item (Carried)

Vote (Adopt Item)

Feb-20-2014 3:36 PM
Result: Carried Majority Required - MM48.33 - Adopt the item
Yes: 41 Paul Ainslie, Maria Augimeri, Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Janet Davis, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Mike Del Grande, Frank Di Giorgio, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Doug Ford, Rob Ford, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Peter Milczyn, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, John Parker, Gord Perks, Anthony Perruzza, Jaye Robinson, David Shiner, Karen Stintz, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam

MM48.34

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:24 
Acquisition of Lands to Complete East/West Road between Rean Drive and Kenaston Gardens - Southeast Bayview Node Context Plan - by Councillor David Shiner, seconded by Councillor Peter Leon
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council request the Director, Real Estate Services, in consultation with the Director of Transportation Services, North York District, the Director, Community Planning, North York District, and the City Solicitor, to identify the land acquisitions necessary to complete the east/west road shown on Map 4 of the Southeast Bayview Node Context Plan, running from Rean Drive to Kenaston Gardens, and to report to Government Management Committee with respect to the means by which those lands may be acquired by the City and the potential cost and source of funds to complete the acquisitions.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.34
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67079.pdf)
Motions (City Council)
Motion to Introduce Motion without Notice moved by Councillor David Shiner (Carried)

That Councillor Shiner be permitted to add to the agenda of today's meeting an urgent Motion without notice concerning:
 
Acquisition of Lands to Complete East/West Road Between Rean Drive and Kenaston Gardens – Southeast Bayview Node Context Plan

 

Reason for Urgency:

 

This motion is urgent due to neighbouring properties along this new roadway are subject to an appeal at the Ontario Municipal Board.  In order for City staff to be able to report to the April 7, 2014 meeting of the Government Management Committee, it is necessary that City Council give consideration of this report request at today's meeting.

MM48.35

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:23 
Revision to the Zoning By-law Amendment for the Property at 49 Hendon Avenue, 26 and 28 Greenview Avenue and 9 to 25 Eldora Avenue - by Councillor John Filion, seconded by Councillor Joe Mihevc
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council amend Zoning By-law 1085-2013 for the lands at 49 Hendon Avenue, 26 and 28 Greenview Avenue and 9 to 25 Eldora Avenue, substantially in accordance with the revised draft Zoning By-law Amendment attached  which includes the following amendments to the Zoning By-law approved by City Council on June 11, 12, and 13, 2013 (NY24.20):

 

Subsection 2(c) be amended to read as follows: "For the purposes of this exception, "established grade" shall mean a geodetic elevation of 191.9 for Blocks A, B and C as shown on Schedule RM1(93) and a geodetic elevation of 193.25 for Blocks D and E as shown on Schedule RM1(93)."

 

2.         City Council determine that the revisions made to the proposed zoning by-law are minor in nature and that, pursuant to subsection 34(17) of the Planning Act, no further public notice is required in respect of the proposed zoning by-law.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.35
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67083.pdf)

Reason for Urgency:

 

This motion is urgent because an amendment is required to provide clarification of the By-law.  Three of the five buildings on this site have had permits issued, and this is to facilitate the intent of the original by-law approval by Council.

MM48.36

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:27 
Release of Section 37 Funds, 66 Isabella Street, for Rainbow-Coloured Pedestrian Crossing Areas and Streetscape Improvements in Celebration of World Pride - by Councillor Kristyn Wong-Tam, seconded by Deputy Mayor Norman Kelly
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.          City Council increase the 2014 Operating Budget for Transportation Services by $50,000 gross, $0 net, fully funded by Section 37 community benefits received from the development at 66 Isabella Street, (source account: 220096), for the purpose of making the east-west pedestrian crossing areas at the Church Street/Isabella Street and Church Street/Alexander Street intersections rainbow-coloured and other identified streetscape improvements in consultation with the General Manager, Transportation Services, in celebration of World Pride.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.36
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67106.pdf)
Motions (City Council)
Motion to Introduce Motion without Notice moved by Councillor Kristyn Wong-Tam (Carried)

That Councillor Wong-Tam be permitted to add to the agenda of today's meeting an urgent Motion without notice concerning:
 
Release of Section 37 Funds, 66 Isabella Street, for Rainbow-Coloured Pedestrian Crossing Areas and Streetscape Improvements in Celebration of World Pride

 

Reason for Urgency:

 

This item is urgent in order for the installation to occur in time for World Pride in June 2014.


Vote (Introduce Motion without Notice)

Feb-20-2014 2:22 PM
Result: Carried Two-Thirds full Council Required - Wong-Tam - Add Urgent Motion
Yes: 41 Paul Ainslie, Maria Augimeri, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Janet Davis, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Mike Del Grande, Frank Di Giorgio, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Doug Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Peter Milczyn, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, John Parker, James Pasternak, Gord Perks, Anthony Perruzza, Jaye Robinson, David Shiner, Karen Stintz, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam

Motion to Adopt Item (Carried)

Vote (Adopt Item)

Feb-20-2014 3:39 PM
Result: Carried Majority Required - MM48.36 - Adopt the item

MM48.37

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

Ward:22 
Authorization to Change the Financial Scope of Phase 8 - Casa Loma Exterior Restoration 2014-2015 Norman Tower to Accommodate Increased Costs - by Councillor Josh Matlow, seconded by Councillor Joe Mihevc
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council approve a change of financial scope to the approved Economic Development and Culture Capital Budget for Phase 8 - Casa Loma Exterior Restoration (CAC089-11) in order to increase the 2015 cash flow by $2,012,974.00 gross/$0 net, fully funded from Casa Loma Corporation revenues.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.37
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67108.pdf)
Motions (City Council)
Motion to Introduce Motion without Notice moved by Councillor Josh Matlow (Carried)

That Councillor Matlow be permitted to add to the agenda of today's meeting an urgent Motion without notice concerning:
 
Authorization to Change the Financial Scope of Phase 8 - Casa Loma Exterior Restoration 2014-2015 Norman Tower to Accommodate Increased Costs

 

Reason for Urgency:

 

This motion is urgent because this budget adjustment needs approval so that a Purchase Order can be issued immediately and construction start by mid-spring of this year.  


Vote (Introduce Motion without Notice)

Feb-20-2014 3:41 PM
Result: Carried Two-Thirds full Council Required - Matlow - Add Urgent Motion
Yes: 40 Paul Ainslie, Maria Augimeri, Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Josh Colle, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Janet Davis, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Frank Di Giorgio, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Peter Milczyn, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, John Parker, James Pasternak, Gord Perks, Anthony Perruzza, Jaye Robinson, David Shiner, Karen Stintz, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam 
No: 2 Doug Ford, Rob Ford 
Absent: 3 Mike Del Grande, Mary Fragedakis, Giorgio Mammoliti

MM48.38

ACTION 

Adopted 

 

 
Employment Contracts regarding Senior Officials of City Agencies, Boards, Commissions and Corporations - by Councillor Michael Thompson, seconded by Councillor Peter Leon
City Council Decision

City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014, adopted the following:

 

1.         City Council direct the City Solicitor and the City Manager to report to the April 23, 2014 meeting of Executive Committee on the legal and policy issues regarding the public disclosure of the contracts of employment of senior officials of the City's Agencies, Boards, Commissions and Corporations.
Background Information (City Council)
Member Motion MM48.38
(http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67126.pdf)
Motions (City Council)
Motion to Introduce Motion without Notice moved by Councillor Michael Thompson (Carried)

That Councillor Thompson be permitted to add to the agenda of today's meeting an urgent Motion without notice concerning:

 

Employment Contracts regarding Senior Officials of City Agencies, Boards, Commissions and Corporations

 

Reason for Urgency:

 

This item is urgent as staff are already preparing a report for the April 2014 Executive Committee meeting and require direction now.


Vote (Introduce Motion without Notice)

Feb-20-2014 11:16 PM
Result: Carried Majority Required - Enact General Bills
Yes: 33 Paul Ainslie, Maria Augimeri, Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Josh Colle, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Rob Ford, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, John Parker, James Pasternak, Gord Perks, David Shiner, Karen Stintz, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam 
No: 1 Anthony Perruzza 
Absent: 11 Janet Davis, Mike Del Grande, Frank Di Giorgio, Doug Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Giorgio Mammoliti, Peter Milczyn, Jaye Robinson 

5 - Motion to Introduce and Pass Confirmatory Bill moved by Councillor John Filion (Carried)

February 20, 2014 at 11:17 p.m. - That leave be granted to introduce a Bill to confirm to the point of the introduction of this motion, the proceedings of Council Meeting 48 on February 19 and 20, 2014.


Vote (Introduce and Pass Confirmatory Bill)

Feb-20-2014 11:17 PM
Result: Carried Majority Required - Introduce the Confirming Bill
Yes: 32 Paul Ainslie, Maria Augimeri, Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Josh Colle, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Rob Ford, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, John Parker, James Pasternak, Gord Perks, David Shiner, Karen Stintz, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam 
No: 2 Paula Fletcher, Anthony Perruzza 
Absent: 11 Janet Davis, Mike Del Grande, Frank Di Giorgio, Doug Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Giorgio Mammoliti, Peter Milczyn, Jaye Robinson 

6 - Motion to Introduce and Pass Confirmatory Bill (Carried)

February 20, 2014 at 11:18 p.m. - That this Bill, prepared for this meeting of Council, be passed and hereby declared as a By-law, as follows: 

 

Bill No.

By-law No.

Status

Title and Authority

135

145-2014

Enacted

To confirm the proceedings of City Council at Meeting 48 held on February 19 and 20, 2014.

(This final confirming By-law confirms all actions taken by Council at this meeting, including the enactment of any previous confirming By-laws.)

 


Vote (Introduce and Pass Confirmatory Bill)

Feb-20-2014 11:18 PM
Result: Carried Majority Required - Enact the Confirming By-law
Yes: 33 Paul Ainslie, Maria Augimeri, Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Josh Colle, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Rob Ford, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, John Parker, James Pasternak, Gord Perks, David Shiner, Karen Stintz, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam 
No: 1 Anthony Perruzza 
Absent: 11 Janet Davis, Mike Del Grande, Frank Di Giorgio, Doug Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Giorgio Mammoliti, Peter Milczyn, Jaye Robinson 

Procedural Motions
1 - Motion to Resolve to Committee of Whole moved by Deputy Mayor Norman Kelly (Withdrawn)

February 19, 2014 at 10:35 a.m. - That Council recess its public session to meet as Committee of the Whole in closed session to consider:

 

LS26.1            The Taxicab Industry Review – Final Report (Ward All)

Reason for Confidential Information - The receiving of advice that is subject to solicitor-client privilege and litigation or potential litigation, including matters before administrative tribunals, affecting the municipality or local board.


2 - Motion to Withdraw a Motion moved by Deputy Mayor Norman Kelly (Carried)

That Deputy Mayor Kelly be permitted to withdraw motion 1 as Members no longer required a closed session.


Vote (Withdraw a Motion)

Feb-19-2014 10:37 AM
Result: Carried Majority Required - Kelly - withdraw motion to resolve to Committee of the Whole on Item LS26.1
Yes: 36 Paul Ainslie, Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Josh Colle, Vincent Crisanti, Janet Davis, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Doug Ford, Rob Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Peter Leon, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Giorgio Mammoliti, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Peter Milczyn, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Ron Moeser, Cesar Palacio, John Parker (Chair), James Pasternak, Gord Perks, Anthony Perruzza, Karen Stintz, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam 
No: 1 Mike Del Grande 
Absent: 8 Maria Augimeri, Gary Crawford, Frank Di Giorgio, Chin Lee, Frances Nunziata, Jaye Robinson, David Shiner, Michael Thompson 

Point of Order by Councillor Giorgio Mammoliti

Councillor Mammoliti, rising on a Point of Order, asked Speaker Nunziata to clarify her request that he turn his T-shirt inside out.


Ruling by Speaker Frances Nunziata
Speaker Nunziata accepted the Point of Order and ruled that Members are prohibited from wearing T shirts containing political slogans as it is contrary to Council's Procedures.

Point of Privilege by Councillor Frank Di Giorgio

Councillor Di Giorgio, rising on a Point of Privilege, stated that comments he made to Tim Alamenciak, and published in The Toronto Star on Thursday, February 13, 2014 were incomplete and taken out of context.  Councillor Di Giorgio further clarified his intended comments and apologized to Chief Bill Blair, Toronto Police Service for any negative associations or connotations that his comments may have caused.


Motion to Recess (Carried)

February 19, 2014 - Speaker Nunziata recessed the meeting for a brief period at 5:34 p.m.


Motion to Recess (Carried)

February 20, 2014 - Speaker Nunziata recessed the meeting for a brief period at 2:15 p.m. to permit Members to watch the end of the gold medal game in Canadian Women's Olympic Hockey.


Motion to Recess moved by Councillor Paula Fletcher (Lost)

February 20, 2014 at 2:23 p.m. - That City Council recess for 20 minutes to permit Members of Council to watch the end of the Canadian Olympic Women's Hockey Game.


Vote (Recess)

Feb-20-2014 2:23 PM
Result: Lost Majority Required - Recess the meeting for the Olympic hockey game
Yes: 17 Paul Ainslie, Gary Crawford, Frank Di Giorgio, Paula Fletcher, Doug Ford, Rob Ford, Mark Grimes, Peter Leon, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, John Parker, Anthony Perruzza, Jaye Robinson 
No: 25 Maria Augimeri, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Raymond Cho, Vincent Crisanti, Janet Davis, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Mike Del Grande, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Mary Fragedakis, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Josh Matlow, Joe Mihevc, Peter Milczyn, Ron Moeser, James Pasternak, Gord Perks, David Shiner, Karen Stintz, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam 
Absent: 3 Ana Bail�o, Josh Colle, Giorgio Mammoliti 

Motion to Recess (Carried)

February 20, 2014 - Speaker Nunziata recessed the meeting for a brief period at 2:52 p.m. to permit Members to watch the overtime in the Canadian Women's Olympic Hockey game.


Motion to Recess (Carried)

February 20, 2014 - Speaker Nunziata recessed the meeting for a brief period at 3:06 p.m.to permit Members of Council to watch the Canadian Women Olympic Hockey Team receive the Gold Medal.


Point of Privilege by Councillor Paula Fletcher

Councillor Fletcher, rising on a Point of Privilege, stated that Mayor Ford was making inappropriate comments to Members, while in the Chamber, about the upcoming election.


Ruling by Speaker Frances Nunziata
Speaker Nunziata accepted the Point of Privilege and ruled that Mayor Ford should stop making remarks concerning the election on the Council Floor and further, that all Members should avoid making such remarks.

Motion to Extend the Meeting moved by Councillor Shelley Carroll (Carried)

February 20, 2014 at 7:42 p.m. – That City Council extend the meeting past the 8:00 p.m. recess in order to complete the agenda.


Vote (Extend the Meeting)

Feb-20-2014 7:42 PM
Result: Carried Two-Thirds Required - Extend the meeting to complete the agenda
Yes: 38 Paul Ainslie, Maria Augimeri, Ana Bail�o, Michelle Berardinetti, Shelley Carroll, Josh Colle, Gary Crawford, Vincent Crisanti, Janet Davis, Glenn De Baeremaeker, Mike Del Grande, Frank Di Giorgio, Sarah Doucette, John Filion, Paula Fletcher, Doug Ford, Rob Ford, Mary Fragedakis, Mark Grimes, Norman Kelly, Mike Layton, Chin Lee, Peter Leon, Josh Matlow, Pam McConnell, Mary-Margaret McMahon, Joe Mihevc, Denzil Minnan-Wong, Ron Moeser, Frances Nunziata (Chair), Cesar Palacio, John Parker, Gord Perks, Jaye Robinson, Karen Stintz, Michael Thompson, Adam Vaughan, Kristyn Wong-Tam 
No: 4 Raymond Cho, Gloria Lindsay Luby, Anthony Perruzza, David Shiner 
Absent: 3 Giorgio Mammoliti, Peter Milczyn, James Pasternak 

Council adjourned on February 20, 2014 at 11:18 p.m.

 

 

 

 

FRANCES NUNZIATA,                                 ULLI S. WATKISS,

Speaker                                                           City Clerk
